summary: A prestigious, hands-on research experience for students interested in interdisciplinary STEM projects. Interns are paired with UC Santa Cruz researchers to participate in authentic lab work and mentorship.

program_name: Stanford AIMI Summer Internship (AI in Medicine)
summary: The Stanford AIMI Summer Internship is an innovative program designed for high school students, introducing them to the practical applications of artificial intelligence in medical diagnostics and health technology. The curriculum combines expert lectures, hands-on coding labs, and in-depth research assignments, providing a comprehensive overview of the intersection between AI and medicine.

A two-day STEM immersion program at Caltech in Pasadena, California, designed to inspire underrepresented students in science. The program is free and open to rising juniors and seniors of all genders. Participants will have the opportunity to engage in research labs, attend informative seminars, and network with prominent Caltech scientists, gaining valuable insight into scientific careers and research.
eligibility_criteria: Rising juniors and seniors (open to all genders)
special_criteria: Designed to inspire underrepresented students in science.

summary: The Caltech Summer Research Connection (SRC) offers high school students from the Pasadena Unified School District the opportunity to join Caltech research teams. Participants contribute to real laboratory projects in fields such as physics, biology, or engineering. The program includes valuable training, mentorship from Caltech researchers, and concludes with students giving final presentations on their work.
eligibility_criteria: Pasadena Unified School District high school students
special_criteria: Must be a student in the Pasadena Unified School District.

program_name: UCSC Teen Research Program (via Lawrence Hall of Science)
summary: A collaborative research program for teens exploring bioengineering, AI, and environmental science. The program offers hands-on experience through live experiments and provides academic instruction led by professional scientists, giving students a direct look into scientific research fields.

A broad-based summer program offering workshops in robotics, computer science, environmental science, and engineering. High school students engage in lab-based learning and problem-solving projects, receiving guidance from university faculty. The program is designed for students from grades 1-12, with a recommendation for upper grades to participate in the research-focused tracks.
special_criteria: Upper grades are recommended for research-focused tracks.

summary: A rigorous academic program offering high school students research-intensive experiences in STEM fields such as physics, neuroscience, and chemistry. Participants earn college credit while collaborating with UCSB faculty on final capstone presentations, gaining valuable hands-on research skills in a university setting.
eligibility_criteria: Open to students in grades 9–11 with a GPA of 3.6 or higher.

summary: This paid, 12-week summer internship allows recent high school graduates to work alongside scientists at Genentech in Oceanside, California. Participants engage in real biotechnology and pharmaceutical research, gaining valuable hands-on experience. The program focuses on developing workplace readiness, essential lab techniques, and provides a foundation for early career development within STEM industries.

program_name: LLNL Biotech Summer Experience (Lawrence Livermore National Lab)
summary: A highly competitive, STEM-rich summer program focused on molecular biology and biotechnology techniques. Students gain hands-on experience in PCR, DNA sequencing, and data science tools within the prestigious setting of a national laboratory. The program is designed for high school juniors and seniors in the Bay Area.
eligibility_criteria: Bay Area high school juniors and seniors
special_criteria: Must be a Bay Area resident.

summary: A pre-medical summer program at Stanford University that explores human anatomy through hands-on experiences like cadaver dissection, 3D imaging, and radiology labs. The program is designed for high school students who are interested in pursuing careers in medicine, surgery, or biological sciences.

A hands-on surgical training program for aspiring pre-med high school students. Participants learn to suture, perform laparoscopic simulations, and explore operating room protocols in a clinical environment using real medical equipment at Stanford University.

The Stanford GRIPS Genomics Internship offers high school students a hands-on experience in cutting-edge life sciences. Participants engage in next-generation genomic sequencing, bioinformatics, and molecular biology research. The program culminates in a student-led analysis project and a formal presentation of their findings, providing a comprehensive introduction to academic research in genomics.

An immersive summer program where high school students dive into neuroscience research labs at Stanford University. Participants attend lectures and explore advanced topics including neural circuits, brain anatomy, and computational neurobiology, culminating in a collaborative final research project.

program_name: Stanford SIMR (Summer Internship in Medicine & Research)
summary: A prestigious, competitive 8-week summer internship at Stanford University for Bay Area high school juniors and seniors. The program offers lab-based rotations in various biomedical research fields such as stem cell biology, cancer, immunology, and genetics. The internship provides hands-on research experience and culminates in a final poster session where students present their findings.
eligibility_criteria: Bay Area high school juniors and seniors
special_criteria: Must be a resident of the Bay Area.

summary: This summer internship at the Jet Propulsion Laboratory offers students the opportunity to work on real NASA projects in fields such as robotics, planetary science, aerospace engineering, and data analysis. Interns are mentored by NASA engineers and scientists, gaining direct exposure to space missions and hands-on research experience.

program_name: UCI Cancer Research Institute Summer Program
summary: This eight-week summer program allows high school juniors and seniors from the Orange County area to work directly in cancer biology labs with UCI researchers. Participants receive hands-on training in key laboratory techniques, including molecular and cellular biology, tissue culture, and genetics. The experience is supplemented with seminars and culminates in a student symposium where they can present their work.
eligibility_criteria: Orange County–area high school juniors and seniors
special_criteria: Restricted to students in the Orange County area.

summary: A 6-week summer research program that places students in UC Davis faculty labs for independent research in genetics, environmental science, and agricultural biology. The program includes university housing and culminates in a final symposium where students present their findings.

A pre-college program for high school students to take official UC Berkeley courses in STEM subjects such as math, chemistry, or computer science. The program combines rigorous academic enrichment with college preparation, peer networking opportunities, and an immersive experience on the university campus.
eligibility_criteria: High school students, ages 16 and older.

program_name: SMASH Academy (Summer Math and Science Honors Academy)
summary: SMASH is a multi-year STEM pipeline program providing academic enrichment, mentorship, and career guidance in coding, math, and science. This free, 5-week summer program is specifically designed for underrepresented 9th-grade students in California from historically marginalized backgrounds to foster their skills and interest in STEM fields.
location: UC Berkeley, UCLA, UC Davis, and other campuses in California
special_criteria: Ideal for students from historically marginalized and underrepresented backgrounds.

program_name: UCSF RISE High School Summer Internship
summary: This biomedical research internship at the University of California, San Francisco is designed for low-income rising juniors and seniors in the Bay Area. The program offers hands-on experience through lab rotations and clinical shadowing, supplemented by college readiness workshops. Participants conclude the internship by presenting their final research at UCSF and receive ongoing mentorship.
eligibility_criteria: Low-income rising juniors and seniors in the Bay Area

summary: Residential and commuter STEM workshops focusing on molecular biology, neuroscience, immunology, and bioinformatics. Held on various university campuses, the program includes lectures, hands-on lab projects, and weekend activities. It is ideal for high school students interested in pursuing biomedical careers and gaining practical experience.
location: UC Berkeley, UC San Diego, Columbia University (NY), and University College London (UK)
duration: Varies, held between June and August

summary: These immersive workshops for high school students cover advanced topics such as molecular neuroscience, cancer biology, bioinformatics, and aging. Programs are led by PhDs and held on prestigious university campuses, featuring hands-on lab instruction, research projects, and residential accommodations for a comprehensive learning experience.
location: UC Berkeley, UC San Diego, Columbia University, University College London
duration: Varies, held between June and August.

summary: A competitive 8-week summer biotech research internship hosted by the Joint BioEnergy Institute. This program offers low-income high school students hands-on lab training, exposure to the biotech industry, and dedicated career mentoring. The program is free, provides a stipend, and includes transportation and meals. It is ideal for students interested in exploring future careers in biotechnology, chemistry, or green energy research.
eligibility_criteria: Low-income 10th and 11th graders in Alameda County

program_name: UC Riverside Bourns Science and Engineering Education Program (SEEP)
summary: The Science and Engineering Education Program (SEEP) at UC Riverside offers high school students from the Inland Empire exposure to various science and engineering disciplines. Through workshops in computer science, robotics, and environmental engineering, the program provides hands-on learning experiences. It is specifically designed to support first-generation college students and STEM-inclined learners from underserved communities, fostering interest in higher education and careers in STEM fields.
special_criteria: Supports first-generation college students and STEM-inclined learners from underserved communities.

program_name: San Diego Biomedical Research Institute High School Internship
summary: This internship allows high school students to engage in hands-on laboratory research focused on significant health issues such as cancer, diabetes, and metabolic disorders. The program is designed to provide real-world experience in biomedical discovery, offering mentorship from PhD scientists and fostering the development of crucial data analysis skills.
eligibility_criteria: High school juniors and seniors in San Diego County.
special_criteria: Applicants must be located in San Diego County.

program_name: California State Summer School for Mathematics and Science (COSMOS)
summary: COSMOS is a 4-week summer residential enrichment program for talented high school students interested in STEM. The program aims to create a community of students who participate in and contribute to an intensive academic experience delivered by distinguished UCI faculty and staff.
eligibility_criteria: Open to talented high school students in grades 9-12.
special_criteria: Residential program. Financial assistance is available.

summary: UC Irvine Sports Camps provide participants of all levels with training and skill development in a variety of sports. Instruction is led by NCAA Division I coaches and student-athletes. The program is designed to promote sportsmanship, foster an appreciation for health and fitness, and increase individual confidence through immersion in a fun, safe, and inclusive learning environment.

Offered by the Claire Trevor School of the Arts, the Summer Academies in the Arts are college and career preparatory intensives for experienced high school and transfer arts students. The program focuses on practical and technical skill development in Art, Dance, Drama, and Music within a challenging and supportive environment.
location: Claire Trevor School of the Arts, University of California, Irvine
eligibility_criteria: Open to students in grades 9-12. Applicants should be experienced high school or transfer arts students.

summary: A digital summer camp experience from the comfort of home, offered by UCI. This program provides a unique opportunity for youth to develop new skills and discover untapped interests. It aims to offer one-of-a-kind experiences to keep campers busy for a few hours each day and give them something to look forward to during the summer.
special_criteria: This is a digital/virtual camp conducted from home.

program_name: UCI’s Writing Project Summer Youth Program
summary: The UCI School of Education’s Writing Project offers an in-person Summer Youth Program designed to further the educational experiences of youth in local communities. Open to students in grades 1-10, all classes are taught by qualified and credentialed instructors, many of whom are UCI Writing Project Fellows. The program is committed to developing expertise and providing enriching learning opportunities for young writers.

program_name: UCI’s Nursing Project Summer Youth Program
summary: A hands-on introductory program for middle and high school students interested in exploring nursing as a career. This program provides early exposure to the many types of nursing, which can significantly influence a student's decision to apply directly to a nursing school out of high school.
eligibility_criteria: Open to middle school students (Session 1) and high school students (Session 2).

program_name: Digital Circuit Design for High Schoolers
summary: This program introduces students to the behavior and movement of electrons in physical components, applying these concepts to the design of everyday electronic products. The curriculum is structured into three major units: Analog electronics fundamentals, focusing on circuits for continuously varying signals; Digital logic circuits, which transform signals using discrete logic levels; and Digital circuit design with High-level Description Languages (HLDs), which covers advanced techniques for real-world signal processing problems.

program_name: CSE-90193 Futures: Analog Circuits for High Schoolers
summary: This program is designed for high school students interested in electrical engineering and computer science. It provides an introduction to the fundamental concepts of analog circuits, offering a foundational understanding of the subject. The course is worth 3.00 units and has a registration cost of $390.00.

program_name: Futures: Digital Logic Circuits for High Schoolers
summary: Not found

program_name: CSE-90195 Futures: Digital Circuit Design with HDL for High Schoolers
summary: Not found

program_name: Robotics with JavaScript for High Schoolers
summary: This program introduces high school students to robotics and automation. Participants learn to program, build, and innovate using the JavaScript language. The curriculum covers real-world robotics challenges, provides practical experience programming an Arduino-compatible bot, and teaches students how to process sensor data, including images from a camera, to make a robot interact with its environment, UCSD.

program_name: Futures: Introduction to Robotics with JavaScript for High Schoolers (CSE-90103)
summary: An introductory program designed for high school students to explore the field of robotics using the JavaScript programming language. This course provides a foundational understanding of robotics principles and coding applications. The program is designated as CSE-90103 and offers 3.00 units of credit upon completion, UCSD

program_name: Futures: Intermediate Robotics with JavaScript for High Schoolers (CSE-90105)
summary: An intermediate-level course designed for high school students to explore the field of robotics using the JavaScript programming language. Offered as part of the Futures program, this course provides hands-on experience in coding for robotic systems. The program is designated as course CSE-90105 and is worth 3.00 units.

program_name: Futures: Advanced Robotics with JavaScript for High Schoolers (CSE-90104)
summary: An advanced program for high school students focusing on the intersection of robotics and programming. Offered through UC San Diego Extended Studies, this course provides hands-on experience using JavaScript to control and operate robotic systems. It is designed to build foundational skills for future studies and careers in technology and engineering. The course offers 3.00 units of credit.

program_name: Futures: Principles of Marketing for High Schoolers
summary: A program designed to introduce high school students to the fundamental concepts and principles of marketing. It provides a foundational understanding for students interested in pursuing business or marketing in their future academic and professional careers. The course offers 3.00 units of credit .

program_name: Futures: Digital Marketing for High Schoolers
summary: A program designed to introduce high school students to the fundamentals of digital marketing. Offered as course BUSA-90071 by UC San Diego Extended Studies, this 3.00-unit course provides a foundational understanding of modern marketing strategies and practices in the digital landscape. It is tailored for pre-college students looking to explore potential career paths or gain a competitive edge in the field of business and marketing. Specific curriculum details, schedule, and format are available on the program website.

program_name: Futures: Content Marketing for High Schoolers
summary: A program designed to introduce high school students to the principles and practices of content marketing. Participants will learn strategies for creating and distributing valuable, relevant, and consistent content to attract and retain a clearly defined audience, earning 3.00 units of credit upon completion.

An introductory program where high school students learn the fundamentals of AutoCAD, starting from the very beginning. The curriculum covers drafting CAD symbols, creating kitchen and bath fixtures, and developing a complete floor plan. Students will master two-dimensional (2D) drawing commands, dimensioning, layering systems, and various drafting techniques. The program culminates in students gaining hands-on experience by developing and assembling a full construction document, including plotting, symbols, and a floor plan.
special_criteria: Designed for beginners, starting from the very beginning.

program_name: Futures: Introduction to AutoCAD for High Schoolers
summary: An introductory course (ARCH-90002) designed for high school students to learn the fundamentals of AutoCAD, a leading computer-aided design (CAD) software. This program provides foundational skills applicable to fields like architecture, engineering, and design. Participants will earn 3.00 units upon successful completion of the course.

program_name: Wireless Communications Technologist for High Schoolers
summary: This program provides high school students with a solid background in popular wireless technologies such as Wi-Fi and Bluetooth, and their applications in the connected world. Participants will explore digital content applications involving audio, video, images, and augmented reality (AR), understanding how the powerful combination of wireless networks and media streaming empowers smart cities, cloud gaming, and on-the-go entertainment, with a focus on AI and the connected world.

program_name: Futures: Bluetooth Technologies and Applications for High Schoolers (EE-90008)
summary: Not found

Experience the energy of an Ivy League campus and take college-level classes with students from around the world. Harvard’s pre-college summer programs for high school students offer both on-campus and virtual options, providing a taste of university life and rigorous academic challenges.
special_criteria: Offers both on-campus and virtual options.

summary: Experience the excitement of New York City while exploring a diverse range of courses, from arts to business and engineering. NYU’s summer programs for high school students offer a unique blend of vibrant city life and world-class academic instruction, providing a taste of college life at a prestigious university.

USC offers immersive summer courses specifically designed for high school students in a variety of subjects, including science, filmmaking, and writing. The program provides opportunities for hands-on projects with expert faculty and social engagement with peers in Los Angeles.

program_name: Washington University in St. Louis Summer Experiences
summary: Washington University in St. Louis offers a variety of summer programs for middle and high school students. Participants can choose from several distinct tracks, including the High School Scholars Program for college credit, specialized High School Institutes, and the Middle School Challenge. Each program is designed to provide an inspiring and challenging academic experience within a vibrant university community, allowing students to explore their interests and prepare for future academic endeavors.
eligibility_criteria: Open to middle and high school students.
special_criteria: The High School Scholars Program offers the opportunity to earn college credit.

summary: A pre-college summer program for ambitious and curious high school students. Participants work one-on-one with world-class mentors to complete their own independent research project. The program is conducted entirely from home, offering a flexible and accessible research experience.

Join a global cohort for rigorous courses in STEM, humanities, and the arts, offered either on campus or online. This program allows participants to experience Stanford’s academic environment and challenge themselves during the summer.

The MIT Research Science Institute is a highly selective, free summer program that provides high school students with the opportunity to work on real-world STEM projects alongside experienced MIT researchers. It offers an intensive, hands-on research experience at one of the world's leading technical institutions.

The Summer Science Program offers a transformative, hands-on opportunity for students to collaborate on advanced research projects in either astronomy or biochemistry. Hosted at top universities, the program is renowned for its immersive and challenging academic environment, allowing participants to engage deeply in real-world scientific inquiry.

program_name: Girls Who Code Summer Immersion Program
summary: The Girls Who Code Summer Immersion Program is a free, virtual initiative designed to empower high school students who identify as girls or non-binary. The program focuses on developing essential coding skills within a supportive and creative online environment, aiming to close the gender gap in technology and build a strong community of future female and non-binary tech leaders.
eligibility_criteria: Open to high school girls and non-binary students.
special_criteria: For students who identify as girls or non-binary.

summary: Camp Neuro is a program for students interested in medicine, offering hands-on learning experiences and opportunities to network with real doctors. The camp focuses on the fields of neuroscience and the broader healthcare industry, providing a practical introduction for those considering a career in medicine.

The Berkeley Pre-College Scholars program offers students the chance to experience UC Berkeley’s renowned academics, participate in engaging activities, and connect with peers from across the globe. The program provides a flexible learning environment with both in-person and online options, giving participants a taste of university life.
special_criteria: Offers both in-person and online participation options.

summary: A fully-funded, prestigious summer program for high-achieving high school students from low-income backgrounds interested in journalism. Held at Princeton University, this immersive experience allows students to learn directly from professional reporters and editors, develop their writing and reporting skills, and receive comprehensive, hands-on college preparation and application guidance. The program aims to diversify the field of journalism by providing access and opportunity to talented students who might not otherwise have it.
eligibility_criteria: High-achieving high school students from low-income backgrounds.

summary: This program provides targeted academic tutoring for elementary school students in grades 3 through 5. The curriculum is designed to offer enrichment and build a strong foundation in core subjects, including reading comprehension, writing skills, and fundamental mathematical concepts. The goal is to enhance students' academic performance and confidence in a supportive learning environment.

This program provides subject-specific tutoring and crucial skill-building for students currently in grades 6 through 8. The core objective is to equip middle schoolers with the academic foundation and learning strategies necessary for a successful transition to and performance in high school.

An academic tutoring program designed for high school students to enhance their Grade Point Average (GPA) and overall college readiness. The program provides focused support across core high school subjects, helping students master difficult concepts, improve their grades, and build a strong academic foundation for their future college applications and studies.
A comprehensive SAT preparation program that includes diagnostic testing, strategy development for test-taking, and targeted skill-building exercises to help students improve their scores.
A program offering targeted ACT preparation, featuring personalized instruction and effective test-taking strategies to help students improve their scores.

A test preparation program designed to help students improve their performance on the PSAT and qualify for National Merit Scholarships. The program focuses on enhancing skills and strategies necessary for success on the standardized test.

The AP Exam Prep Program offers personalized, one-on-one tutoring designed to help high school students excel in their Advanced Placement exams. The primary goal of the program is to equip students with the knowledge and test-taking strategies necessary to achieve high scores, potentially earning them valuable college credit before they even begin their undergraduate studies. This focused preparation aims to build confidence and mastery of complex subjects covered in the AP curriculum.
eligibility_criteria: High school students preparing for Advanced Placement (AP) exams.

summary: A specialized test preparation program designed to help students prepare for private school admissions exams, specifically the Secondary School Admission Test (SSAT) and the Independent School Entrance Exam (ISEE). The program focuses on equipping students with the strategies and knowledge needed to excel in all sections of these standardized tests, which are a common requirement for admission into many private and independent schools.

This program provides comprehensive support for students throughout the entire college application process. Key services include assistance with school selection to find the best fit, expert guidance and help with crafting compelling application essays, and developing an overall strategy to enhance the student's admission prospects.

This refers to the mandatory academic standards set by the California Department of Education regarding Algebra I. It is not an optional program but a core requirement that all high school students must satisfy to be eligible for graduation. The requirement ensures students achieve a foundational level of mathematical proficiency necessary for a high school diploma. The details specify the course content and competencies students must demonstrate.
eligibility_criteria: This is a mandatory requirement for all high school students in California seeking a diploma.

The California School Recognition Program is an initiative by the California Department of Education to identify and honor outstanding schools within the state. It acknowledges schools for their significant achievements in creating positive learning environments and demonstrating academic excellence. The program celebrates the efforts of teachers, administrators, and students in achieving high educational standards. Further details about the specific awards or recognition criteria are not available in the provided text.

Career-Technical Education (CTE) provides high school students with a sequence of courses that integrates core academic knowledge with technical and occupational skills. These programs are designed to prepare students for a wide range of high-skill, high-wage careers and further education by providing hands-on learning experiences in various industry sectors. The goal is to make education relevant and engaging, linking learning to real-world applications and future career paths within the California public school system.

This document outlines the mathematics requirements for high school graduation as specified by the California Department of Education. It is not a specific program or course, but rather a set of standards and guidelines that students must meet to receive their high school diploma within the state.

A directory of specialized secondary programs offered through the California Department of Education. These programs are designed for high school students and provide focused learning opportunities in various fields to enhance college and career readiness beyond the standard high school curriculum.

program_name: State Minimum High School Graduation Requirements
summary: This refers to the set of academic standards established by the California Department of Education (CDE) that students in public high schools must meet to earn a diploma. The requirements specify the courses and credits needed across various subjects, including English, mathematics, science, social science, and physical education. This is a regulatory framework for education rather than a specific program that students apply to or enroll in.
eligibility_criteria: Applicable to all students enrolled in California public high schools seeking a high school diploma.

program_name: Courses Required for California Public University
summary: This resource from the California Department of Education outlines the specific high school course requirements, commonly known as the A-G requirements, that students must complete to be eligible for admission to the state's public university systems, including the University of California (UC) and California State University (CSU). It serves as a foundational guide for students, parents, and counselors to ensure academic preparation for higher education within California.
eligibility_criteria: High school students planning to apply to a California public university.

summary: Not found
